entry.title: Rigid Body Motion
entry.content:
This tutorials is for rigid body motion, including rotation, rigid-body motion and corresponding velocity. Finally the wrench is given in this tutorials.

Rigid Body Motion

Rigid body motion means that: given any two points ppp and qqq, which must satisfy the following formula

∥p(t)−q(t)∥=∥p(0)−q(0)∥=const\|p(t)-q(t)\|=\|p(0)-q(0)\|=const∥p(t)−q(t)∥=∥p(0)−q(0)∥=const

Besides, rigid body transformation has the following properties

  • Preserved length. Given mapping g:R3→R3g:\mathbb{R}^3\to \mathbb{R}^3g:R3→R3, ∥g(p)−g(q)∥=∥p−q∥\|g(p)-g(q)\|=\|p-q\|∥g(p)−g(q)∥=∥p−q∥ holds.
  • Preserved cross product. Given mapping g:R3→R3g:\mathbb{R}^3\to \mathbb{R}^3g:R3→R3, g∗(v×ω)=g∗(v)×g∗(ω)g_*(v\times \omega)=g_*(v)\times g_*(\omega)g∗​(v×ω)=g∗​(v)×g∗​(ω)

Rotation Motion

In order to describe the orientation of rigid body, the frame is attached to rigid body. The relative pose can be defined as 3×33\times33×3 matrix:

Rab=[x⃗aby⃗abz⃗ab]R_{ab}=[{\vec{x}}_{ab} \quad {\vec{y}}_{ab} \quad{\vec{z}}_{ab}]Rab​=[xab​y​ab​zab​]

Properties of RRR

  • The columns of R∈R3×3R\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times3}R∈R3×3, which is r⃗1,r⃗2,r⃗3∈R3\vec{r}_1,\vec{r}_2,\vec{r}_3 \in \mathbb{R}^3r1​,r2​,r3​∈R3, are mutually orthonormal. It can be written as

    RRT=RTR=I,detR=+1RR^T=R^TR=I, detR=+1RRT=RTR=I,detR=+1

    cautions: the rotation matrix has 9 parameters, including 6 constraints (3 for orthogonality and 3 for dot product equal to 1.)

  • R∈SO(3)R\in SO(3)R∈SO(3). In general, the group satisfies the following axioms: Closure, Identity, Inverse, Associativity. The axioms is validated for SO(3)SO(3)SO(3).

    SO(3)={R∈R3:RRT=I,detR=+1}SO(3)=\{R\in\mathbb{R}^3:RR^T=I,detR=+1\}SO(3)={R∈R3:RRT=I,detR=+1}

Basic Calculation

  • Composition rule. Rac=RabRbcR_{ac}=R_{ab}R_{bc}Rac​=Rab​Rbc​

  • Cross product. Given two vectors a,b∈R3a,b\in \mathbb{R^3}a,b∈R3, the cross product is defined as

    a×b=[a2b3−a3b2a3b1−a1b3a1b2−a2b1]a\times b=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} a_2b_3-a_3b_2 \\ a_3b_1-a_1b_3 \\ a_1b_2-a_2b_1 \\ \end{array}\right]a×b=⎣⎡​a2​b3​−a3​b2​a3​b1​−a1​b3​a1​b2​−a2​b1​​⎦⎤​

    Since the product is a linear operator, b↦a×bb\mapsto a\times bb↦a×b , can be represented using a matrix. Defining skew matrix

    a∧=[0−a3a2a30−a1−a2a10]a^{\wedge}=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 0 && -a_3 && a_2\\ a_3 && 0 && -a_1\\ -a_2 && a_1 && 0\\ \end{array}\right]a∧=⎣⎡​0a3​−a2​​​−a3​0a1​​​a2​−a1​0​⎦⎤​

    we can write

    a×b=a∧ba\times b=a^{\wedge}ba×b=a∧b

    • ​Cross product properties.

      R(v×w)=(Rv)×(Rw)R(v\times w)=(Rv)\times(Rw) R(v×w)=(Rv)×(Rw)

R(w)∧RT=(Rw)∧ R(w)^{\wedge}R^T=(Rw)^{\wedge}R(w)∧RT=(Rw)∧

Caution: Cross product operator lies in Lie algebra space so(3)so(3)so(3). It is analogy to tangent space in Lie algebra space.

Exponential coordinates for rotation

As for a condition for a joint rotated along axis ω⃗\vec\omegaω, the velocity of a point qqq, in rigid body, can be written as

q˙(t)=ω×q(t)=ω∧q(t)\dot{q}(t)=\omega\times q(t)={\omega}^\wedge q(t)q˙​(t)=ω×q(t)=ω∧q(t)

This is a time-invariant linear differential equation and the solution can be expressed as

q(t)=eωtq(0)q(t)={e^{\omega t}}q(0)q(t)=eωtq(0)

where q(0)q(0)q(0) is the initial position and eωte^{ \omega t}eωt is the matrix exponential (Taylor expansion to calculate it).

Quaternion is usually used in robotics, for example ROS, due to non-singularity.

Rigid Motion

Generally, rigid-body motion can be divided into two parts: translation p∈R3p\in\mathbb{R^3}p∈R3 and rotation R∈SO(3)R\in SO(3)R∈SO(3). A configuration of the rigid body is the product space of R3\mathbb R^3R3 with SO(3)SO(3)SO(3), which is denoted as SE(3)SE(3)SE(3) (for special Euclidean group):

SE(3)={(p,R):p∈R3,R∈SO(3)}=R3×SO(3)SE(3)=\{(p,R):p\in\mathbb{R^3},R\in SO(3) \}=\mathbb{R^3}\times SO(3)SE(3)={(p,R):p∈R3,R∈SO(3)}=R3×SO(3)

Homogeneous representation

Given 4×44\times 44×4 matrix gab∈SE(3)g_{ab}\in SE(3)gab​∈SE(3), the homogeneous representation is written as

gab=[Rabpab01],the frame b is relative to frame b.g_{ab}=\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} R_{ab} && p_{ab} \\ 0 && 1 \\ \end{array}\right],the\ frame\ b\ is\ relative\ to\ frame\ b.gab​=[Rab​0​​pab​1​],the frame b is relative to frame b.

Twists

Exponential coordinates for SE(3)SE(3)SE(3)

Analogy to the SO(3)SO(3)SO(3) coordinates expression, SE(3)SE(3)SE(3) is also can be obtained by differential equation. The tangent space of SE(3)SE(3)SE(3) is se(3)se(3)se(3), which is called twists.

Consider the 1-joint robot as shown in Figure, where the rotation axis is ω∈R3,∥ω∥=1\omega\in \mathbb{R^3},\|\omega\|=1ω∈R3,∥ω∥=1, and q∈R3q \in \mathbb{R^3}q∈R3 is the point on the axis. Then, the velocity of the tip point, p(t)p(t)p(t), is

p˙(t)=ω×(p(t)−q)\dot{p}(t)=\omega\times(p(t)-q)p˙​(t)=ω×(p(t)−q)
